Comments_List: I learned more about economic challenges concerning developing countries.
An introduction to many topics in development economics that was useful for me, especially being more of a security interest in global affairs.

An overview of topics in development studies, such as agriculture, role of institutions, impact of conflicts. Some econometric techniques (Randomized Control Trials, Difference-in-Differences, Instrumental Variables).

-a broad overview of various aspects of economic development, part theoretical & part empirical, examined several studies

Learned about international development with a focus on skills to evaluate development projects. Topics included financial growth, health, education, population, conflict, Microfinance, institutions, etc.

This class provided a foundation for several core concepts of development: poverty and inequality, economic growth theories, structural transformation, migration, microfinance, institutions, etc. As a survey course, it really did seem like an introductory international development course and helped lay down a lot of basic knowledge for me (as someone new to the Global major). I thought the economics and statistics we learned were what was necessary for the course, so it also felt useful to build up that quantitative aspect as well. All in all, really glad I took this class.
analytical thinking regarding economic development - different theories
The course provides a broad overview of topics in the field of development and a working knowledge of some basic statistical principles important to the field (RCTs, instrumental variables, etc.).
A lot about dev. economics, what works and what doesn't work
I learned about development economics

By taking this course, I learned the foundations of international development. This includes the different theories that economists have come up with in relations to development, different experiments and RCTs and their outcomes, and areas of international development in which further exploration and experimentation is needed.
Economic development, econometrics, trial evaluation

Knowledge:
	Basic definitions and parameters of development economics
	Major geographic trends, patterns and facts about the worlds development and metrics over the past few years
	Landmark findings in the development economics literature and competing theories
	Measurement of outcomes in health, education welfare/inequality, conflict, political institutions
	Economic philosophy i.e. informational asymmetries, moral hazard, opportunity costs, rapacity, coordination problems, commitment problems in international development
Skills:
	Basic econometric techniques e.g. selection bias, RCT regressions, instrumental variables (two step regression), difference in differences, Solow growth model, Cobb Dougglas/production functions
	Reading some tough economics papers and getting the key message
	Thinking about isolating causality extensively and rejecting superficial correlation
Insights:
	The breakthrough of institutions as a quantitative, measurable and real parameter of development
	The rigorous process and consciousness involved in establishing causality
The economic worldview and lens of using incentives to explain actions and outcomes
I learned some basic theory about development through a number of different studies.

GLBL 225 improved my understanding of the basic mechanics of development economics. Many of the concepts we learned felt intuitive because they are implicit in other global classes. As a result, this serves as a helpful structure for incorporating knowledge from many other classes in global.
I thought the class tied everything that we had been learning in our electives together.
I became familiar with various research methods and topics in development.

Weakness was participation being a grade in a lecture course, this component of the grade should be removed. Strength was the format of 3 exams and a presentation, it made for learning the material much better.

Weaknesses: very few questions on exams and extremely determinant of grade percentages

Strengths: Material is very clearly presented. Professor Amodio comprehensively answers any and all questions during class.

strengths: 
-this course covers important topics and could be a good orienting framework towards approaching international affairs as a whole. I think everyone should be challenged to consider problems through an economic lens at one point or another. 
-(as taught by current prof - the prof seems to change every year) used a lot of empirical studies to tease out nuances in each issue

weaknesses: 
-exams account for basically entirety of course and are unfairly graded (you get negative points for missing questions) while also having very unclear wording. i often thought the content material tested was fair, but the way questions were phrased (especially in multiple choice) made it difficult to ascertain what the prof was looking for 
-as taught by amodio, there's no curve in this class. be forewarned.
The tests where very difficult, but not in relation to the material, rather the questions were tricky and vague in a way that hindered my ability to show my knowledge of the subject.

The course was a great survey of international development, and I think it worked as a very comprehensive introduction to the discipline. I do hope the grading was such that we didnt get negative points for answering a multiple choice question wrong, though. I dont think it really serves any educational merit.

This was the worst class I have taken at Yale so far. While initially it seemed that the course would be fine because its structure, I was very disappointed. Lecture was extremely dull, and honestly useless. I would have been better off staying at home and just looking at the slides than attending, but attendance was required. The tests were horribly written and did not judge a student's knowledge of the material at all. A large part of this was due to very poor wording of multiple choice questions, which often had multiple "right" answers in the eyes of many students. The fact that we had to go over the tests in section before even getting our exams back was a miserable experience. Section was also a complete waste of time. It did not add to the course at all. In the end, I was only in this course because it is a major requirement, so I tried to come in with an open mind, but after each class I became more and more disappointed and disillusioned with the class. I don't know of a single person who liked it.

The course was well structured though I wish there had been problem sets.  The lectures were extremely clear and well thought out- the weakness was the student engagement (This is a larger reflection on the Global Affairs major in general but a solid proportion of students don't come to class and then complain about their grade toward the end as soon as they realize that participation/engagement in lecture counts as a portion of one's grade.  Francesco is wonderful professor but the students drove me CRAZY mainly because the way they behaved manifested in my mind as a lack of respect for someone who we are so lucky to have tech this class in a clear, thoughtful manner- their laziness and expectation to excel despite not putting in the work was mind boggling).
It would be good if it  was more quantitative.
Better section structuring- I didn't like going over the exam scores in class without receiving my actual exam.

Strengths: Intro level material that was presented in clear, legible ways. I appreciated the deeper look into multiple case studies and academic research currently occurring. 

Weakness: Likely too intro level for the caliber of the class -- given that we are almost all 3rd and 4th year year students, many of us had encountered this material before. I think this class could have been a good opportunity to take more nuanced dives into topics of development with a critical lens. I would have liked to have seen more about public-private partnerships that are currently taking place, rather than more basic level studies. Grading was a bit weird -- I think it would have been better to give slightly harder to tests (more written) and maybe a paper.

Going to lecture and discussion sections were really a core part of my experience in this course. Professor Amodio really is a great lecturer and has a knack at explaining complicated concepts in a clear, concise manner. He also is great at playing the class discussion off of student questions, which is why participation is so important! I thought the lectures did a great job at summarizing the core concepts from the textbook chapters, as well as applying them to the interesting readings that were assigned--real-life empirical studies that I might not have fully grasped without the help of lecture. Discussion sections were also run efficiently--each minute in section was used wisely and I felt like they all had purpose to them. I suppose some might ask for more assignments or tasks to help distinguish the grade distribution, but I felt like the workload of the class was really optimal for me.

By my knowledge, the course this year was wildly different than it was taught in the past, when most students absolutely loathed it. From my experience, it is a good course for what it is meant to be: a survey on topics in development. Grading was a bit arbitrary (my participation grade as someone who attended class regularly was the same as someone who did not attend any class since the second week), but I think this is something that will improve with time.

Strengths- interesting
Weakness- could feel like a gut at times

This course could benefit from either eliminating section or making it more engaging. Additionally, a lot of the material while interesting was presented in a lackluster way that was not necessarily critical of the neoliberal, paternalistic, and capitalistic elements that drive current discourses on international development. I would have loved to have had the opportunity to discuss the underlying theories that drive the particular manifestations of development in the 21st century. As a Latin American, I would have appreciated discourse on extractive industries (AJR theory) beyond noting that they were extractive. The history of political economy is critical to understanding that our perceptions of development are not sustainable. As a foundational course for he global major, the information was useful but left me worried about the gaps in knowledge and criticism about current development approaches.

In terms of strengths, the set-up of the course was well organized and nicely planned. Lectures by Professor Amodio were comprehensive and thorough, and sections complemented the lectures very nicely. I appreciated the focus on qualitative aspects of the course. In terms of weaknesses, I thought that the review sessions in sections for the midterms could be more well though-out, as they could sometimes be uncomfortable and stress-inducing, as students in section start to admit what they got wrong and what they got correct on the exam.

Great, easy introduction to development economics, basic econometric techniques, economic philosophy and the lens of an economist on the worlds welfare and future.

Instructor:
	Professor Amodio was visiting this year but did a very good job. He is a great lecturer even though he is not the best orator. If one listens carefully (not easy at 9 am), he says a lot of interesting things and always connects examples and facts to take-away principles, theories and great big ideas
	He did a very good job with interaction in the beginning and asked a range of easy, difficult and fun questions in class for us to answer. However, by the end, he would ask no more than one question in class and interaction became limited to people asking him silly questions rather than engaging with the content/debate. The participation grade created perverse incentives for people to say things and ask stupid questions for the sake of the grade, to the detriment and waste of time of everybody. Professor Amodio talks a lot about incentives but he did not recognize the problem here and said the grade was based on quantity rather than quality of participation (just say anything it seemed)
Class content (lecture):
	The slides were very well prepared and did a great job summarizing information. Once in a while e.g. difference in differences or with the rural urban migration papers details, the slides were unclear and did not hammer home on a central message
	The class time was well managed and would always end well/punctually 
Class content (readings):
	The book wasnt needed for the class but it was very interesting (and a short) read and really took the lectures to the next level
	The papers for the Section were also a nice balance but again a higher expectation should be set with reading and discussing the papers
Course assignments:
	The professor and everyone realized that the class was too easy and except the first exam (that had one somewhat harder question on Solow), the exams were descriptive and too basic.
	The MCQs on the exam were somewhat harder and required a solid understanding of what was going on. The negative marking on incorrect guesses wasnt necessary. Sadly  and this is unfortunate  the English language of some of the MCQs was unclear. Professor Amodio is not a native speaker so this is fine but I suggest he write harder essay questions rather than try to make the multiple choice complex and niche
	There were no problem sets, which while the students enjoyed, was probably not a good idea. The econometric techniques could have really been driven home by short biweekly (not weekly) problem sets with simple/fundamental math e.g. doing a two-step regression in Excel, coming up with potential instrumental variables, interpreting difference in differences results
Section
	The presentation was a useful and insightful exercise and we put in a good amount of effort understanding our paper
	The papers assigned for reading, exam reviews, solutions and discussions were a good idea
Improvements: make the exams harder (essay questions), expect students to read some papers in full, add problem sets, remove the lecture participation grade (or transfer it to Section), teach some complex math/dont dilute the math to make it easier for students

The main strength of this class is the emphasis on critical analysis of different studies and research techniques. Many of the studies we looked at were interesting and we were taught to try to find flaws with them, which I believe to be an important skill. In terms of weaknesses, overall, the course felt like it lacked unity, other than the very broad theme of development. The different topic sections were a bit disjointed. The instruction was very poor, but the professor is leaving after this semester so that is not relevant to future iterations of the course. Weekly discussion section was a waste of time: there was no productive discussion, and nothing outside of what we learned in class was brought up by the teaching fellow. The requirement that every student participate by asking a question in every class was ludicrous and detracted greatly from the quality of the class. We were told that we needed to participate in each class to receive full participation points, and that the quality of our questions was not important, so students were incentivized to say anything for the sake of talking, leading to many unproductive questions and points. The tests were poorly made and poorly graded. The multiple choice questions were often worded ambiguously and seemed designed to trick students. The short answer questions were graded according to a very specific, inflexible rubric, so one could demonstrate full knowledge of the subject and lose points for failing to mention an incidental detail. Overall, this course had far more weaknesses than strengths.

Professor Amodio is a strong lecturer and the TFs were also very knowledgeable. Professor Amodio did a very good job of explaining complicated concepts in a simple manner. That said, the course didn't feel like it had too much content. Perhaps I would have felt overwhelmed by a more quantitative course, but a large part of me wishes that there had been more math and that we had incorporated Stata or R. One other consideration, is that the first time a person can take GLBL 225 is their sophomore spring (after having been accepted to global affairs). As a result, many students in the class have already taken a large number of more advanced global classes and/or economics. GLBL 225 might be more helpful earlier. The course was incredibly user-friendly and the textbook was a helpful supplement. Professor Amodio also picked very good readings. Section time was well used and interested.

The lectures were great, and the material was interesting.  It was well structured in terms of teaching.  The review sessions for exams should go beyond just going through a practice test (which was super helpful).  The grading for the exams was also a little weird.  I wish there were more opportunities for feedback besides the exams
People should take it before junior spring but thats a problem with the major and not the course

While this course gave a wide overview of international development, I do not think it expected enough of students. Sometimes lectures gave fairly elementary, cursory glances at topics, and I think that the course would be better if it was more in-depth and taught to a higher level.

The information was presented in a clear manner.

It was a good class that exposed you to the contours of development economics.

ABSOLUTELY but really only if this professor were teaching it again.
I would never take this course if I didn't have to. Unstructured and ambiguous the whole time.

Unless this course has undergone *significant* changes, I would not recommend it in the slightest. As someone interested in the field, this class was a sincere disappointment in its (1) provincial view of international development and (2) high school level engagement of the material. With the former, we did not discuss multiple important components of int'l dev, ranging from nonprofits to historical context for the regions we discussed. In terms of the latter, there were no papers, just three exams that required memorization of lecture slides -- and not much more.
I do think Professor Amodio is a kind person, but I sincerely hope the course gets revitalized for the next cohort of students.
If you have to take it, you have to take it. But other than that no

Required class. Overall, interesting intro level material to international development. It's a topic I find naturally interesting but I think the class was a little too basic in its approach. Hopefully it will become more nuanced over the years.

This class was honestly what I had expected of an intro development economics course--in terms of the course material covered--but what I was surprised by was how much I learned. Even though this is required for Global majors, I look back on this course not as a tedious requirement I had to fulfill, but rather an interesting and comprehensive class that set up a lot of foundational skills I could take elsewhere in the Global major (as an intro required course should actually be!). While you do get the necessary economics and statistical teaching to understand the readings and lectures, I appreciated how the class wasn't focused on just learning those concepts, but rather applying them to broader frameworks within development. As someone who came in interested in development economics and international development in general, but not knowing too much, I am really grateful I took this class early on because now I feel much better prepared for other classes. As a last note, at least with Professor Amodio, participate! Your experience and the experience of your classmates can only be improved by asking questions.
I found the material very interesting and engaging - causing me to develop a strong understanding of RCTs - very useful

Everyone taking this course was doing so because they had to for the major, but I actually would recommend this course to anyone looking for an introduction to the field of development economics. It played off well with the other more advanced development courses I was taking this semester, and I appreciated it in my schedule!
Yeah except the curve could kill you

You have to take this course as a Global major but approach this class knowing that it is not all encompassing of development theory. Please question, discuss and interrogate topics in the class and even the post-colonial nature in developing countries as well as the underlying neoliberal tilt.

This course, compared to previous iterations of GLBL 225, was I think much better and thus I would recommend it. However, when evaluating the course as a whole, I don't think it changed my opinion of international development, or caused me to approach the subject in a different way/create a better appreciation for international development.

This class was IMMENSELY frustrating. I will say that Professor Amodio knows his stuff and he organized the course well. Unfortunately, being given a 9am slot at the Watson Center is never easy. The material was neither interesting nor challenging. However, these components of the class did not doom it. Rather, it was the exams that made this class so excruciating. 

Three exams covered the basics of the material. You just have to regurgitate what was on the slides. Literally, if you put an ounce of thought into a question, you were likely to get it wrong. The exams were designed to trick and frustrate you in a way I had never experienced in a Yale class. I've never taken a class that discouraged analytical thinking in such a way. 

The material, at its core, could have been interesting. It was well-presented and clear. We did learn some nifty things about development. But these moments were far and few between. Most of this class was spent panicking over how unbelievably annoying the exams were. With a different form of assessment, this class could be completely changed.
